loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija has her own small shop in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to the Sisikwasisi group loan (Group code 2042). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $25. Every day she works at her business. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her busines.

Khadija is 27 years old, married, and has four children: ages 9, 6, 3 and 1.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Maryam

texts.en:
Maryam has her own small shop and has been a juice and bites seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for 4 years. She belongs to the Jitahidi group loan (Group code 2014). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $195. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more breads for her business. She is hoping her profit will increase through this loan, and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use, improve her home and pay school fees for her children.

Maryam is 46 years old, married, and has three children: ages 12, 9 and 6. She also cares for four additional dependants. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Alesi, Hadija, and Veis. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more items (cooking oil and flour) for her business.

loans.name: Maryam

texts.en:
Maryam has been a clothes seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She belongs to the Mombasa Two group loan (Group code 2052). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. Every day she works at her business for 7 hours. She is requesting a loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Maryam is 37 years old, married, and has five children: ages 20, 16, 12, 9 and 5.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella F. sells groceries like biscuits and canned products near the Elmina police station. Stella has received junior high education. She is married and has 4 children; her husband is a trader. Stella has been selling groceries since 2001. She is responsible for paying house keeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family’s financial needs. Her loan will be used to buy more groceries to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards a house she wants to put up for the children with her husband.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more groceries to meet the increase in demand by her customers.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha has been a cloth, charcoal, and firewood seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for 4 years. She belongs to Safi Nia Group. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 60.Every day she works at her business from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more "khanga" (traditional Tanzanian cloth), charcoal, and firewood for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Asha is 28 years old, married, and has four children: ages between 9 and 6. She also cares for one additional dependent.

loans.use: To buy more  "khanga," charcoal and firewood for her business

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick T. sells videos, music CDs and DVDs at Santsiwadzie near Elmina. Patrick has received senior high school education. He is married and has no children. His wife is a seamstress.

Patrick has been selling videos and music CDs and DVDs since 1999. He is responsible for paying rent, utility bills, and other expenses. His loan will be used as additional capital to enable him to increase the sale of videos, CDs, and DVDs for both foreign and local movies and music to meet the increase in demand by his customers. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to save towards a house he wants to put up for his children.

loans.use: additional capital for the sale of video CDs and DVDs

loans.name: Tawakal Kwa Mola Group

texts.en:
Maimuna has been a fish seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for 1 year. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 90. Every day she works at her business for 7 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more fish for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Maimuna is 23 years old and single. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Munawar and Fatma. Each woman has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

loans.name: Samha

texts.en:
Samha owns a small charcoal store and is a cloth seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to Tujitegemee Group. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 70. Every day she works at her business from 8 a.m. to 11 p.m. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and cloth for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Samha is 39 years old, married, and has eight children: ages 25, 22, 20, 16, 15, 10, 9, and 5.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and cloth for her business.

loans.name: Auntie Ekua

texts.en:
Auntie Ekua B. is married and has 3 children. She has received no formal education. Auntie Ekua sells fish which she buys from the fishermen, bringing them home for processing and preservation, and then sending them to the market for sale at Asamapon near Elmina, which she has done since 1980. Her husband is a fisherman.

Auntie Ekua uses her income to pay housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family’s other financial needs. Auntie Ekua will use the loan to increase her capital to buy fish in larger quantities for processing and sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Auntie Ekua plans to save towards a house she wants to put up for her children with her husband.

loans.use: increase her capital to buy fish in larger quantities

loans.name: Safia

texts.en:
Safia has been a food flavor seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She belongs to Tujikomboe Group (Group code 2004). Every day she works at her business. She is requesting a loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more flavor items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Safia is 42 years old, married, and has six children: ages 15, 13, 11, twins who are 9, and 5.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Kazija

texts.en:
Kazija is a chips seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to Tunajaribu Group (Group code 2014). She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 25. Every day she works at her business. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more Irish potatoes and cooking oil for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Kazija is 29 years old, married, and has two children: ages 4 and 2.

loans.use: To buy more Irish potatoes and cooking oil for her business

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris B. sells fish which she buys from the fishermen, bringing them home for processing and preservation, and then sending them to the market for sale at Mpoben near Elmina. Doris has received primary level education. She is married and has 2 children.

Doris has been selling fish since 1999. She is responsible for paying utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Her loan will be used to increase her capital to buy fish in larger quantities for processing and sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards acquiring a piece of land for the building of a family house so that they can stop paying rent and also get a comfortable shelter for the family.

loans.use: increase her capital to buy fish in larger quantities for processing and sale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary T. sells groceries such as biscuits and canned products and also prepares food for sale at Asamapon near Elmina. Mary has received junior high education. She is married and has 2 children, her husband is a mason. Mary has been selling groceries and also preparing food for sale since 2000. She is responsible for paying housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family’s other financial needs.

Her loan will be used to buy more groceries and ingredients for food preparation to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards a house she wants to put up for her children with her husband.

loans.use: buy more groceries and ingredients for  food preparation

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia A. is married and has 5 children. She has received schooling through primary level. Cecilia sells a variety of cooked food at Liverpool Street in Elmina, which she has done since 1988. Her husband is a fisherman. Cecilia uses her income to pay housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family’s other financial needs.

Cecilia will use the loan to purchase more ingredients for food preparation to meet the increase in demand by her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Cecilia plans to save towards a house she wants to put up for her children with her husband.

loans.use: purchase more ingredients for food preparation

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia A. sells fish which she buys from the fishermen, bringing them home for processing and preservation, and then sending them to the market for sale. Felicia has received junior high school education. She is married and has 2 children; her husband is a fisherman.

Felicia has been selling fish since 2002. She is responsible for paying housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family’s other financial needs. Her loan will be used to increase her capital to buy fish in larger quantities for processing and sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards a house she wants to put up for her children with her husband.

loans.use: increase her capital to buy fish in larger quantities for processing and sale

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna F. is a single parent and has 2 children. She has received schooling through junior high. Anna sells plastic products and soft drinks near the Elmina police station, which she has done since 2003. Anna uses her income to pay rent, utility bills, and other financial expenses.

Anna will use the loan to purchase more plastic products and soft drinks to meet the increase in demand by her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Anna plans to reinvest for the expansion of her trade.

loans.use: A purchase more plastic products and soft drinks for re-sale

loans.name: Cindy

texts.en:
Cindy B. is married and has one child. She has received schooling through junior high. Cindy is a hairdresser who owns a beauty salon at Pedu near Abura, which she has done for about 2 years. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Cindy uses her income to pay for housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family’s other financial needs. Cindy will use the loan to purchase different varieties of hair products to meet the demand of her customers who come to the salon. With the new profits from her expanded business, Cindy plans to reinvest for the expansion of her little business.

loans.use: purchase different varieties of hair products

loans.name: Kassum

texts.en: Kassum A. sells used clothing at Abura. Kassum has received primary level education.  She is married and has 2 children. Her husband is a commercial driver. Kassum has been selling used clothing for about 2 years. She is responsible for paying housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family's other financial needs. Her loan will be used to as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of used clothing to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits to reinvest for the expansion of  her little business.

loans.use: additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of used clothing

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa A. sells cooked rice and beans at the Abura Police site. Hawa has received no formal education. She is married and has 4 dependents. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Hawa has been selling rice and beans for about 13 years. She is responsible for paying housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family's other financial needs. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of rice and beans to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest for the expansion of her little cooked food business.

loans.use: additional capital for the sale of rice and beans

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica D. sells fabric and sewing materials at Abura. Veronica has received senior high education. She is married and has 5 dependents. Veronica has been selling fabric and sewing materials for about 8 years. She is responsible for paying housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family's other financial needs. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of fabric and sewing materials to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest for the expansion of  her little sewing notions business.

loans.use: additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of fabric, etc.

loans.name: Adamu

texts.en: Adamu H. makes and sells a corn drink at Abura. Adamu has received no formal education.  She is single and has no children. Adamu has been selling this corn drink for about 4 years. She is responsible for paying paying rent, utility bills and other expenses. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to buy more corn to increase the sale of corn drinks to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits to reinvest for the expansion of  her little business.

loans.use: additional capital to enable her buy more corn

loans.name: Rakia

texts.en:
Rakia Z., married to a commercial driver and with seven dependents, was educated through junior high school. Since 1987, she has prepared food for sale and sold foodstuffs such as maize and plantain at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast. Rakia uses her income to help support her husband in paying rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family.

Rakia is now requesting a loan as additional capital to buy more food supplies to meet increased customer demand. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save towards acquiring a piece of land upon which to build the family home in order to stop paying rent and have a comfortable shelter for the family.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more food supplies to meet increased customer demand.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana O. is a single parent and has 1 child. She has received schooling through senior high. Juliana sells fabric, babies' wear and cosmetics at Twifo Praso Near Cape Coast, which she has done since 1999. Juliana uses her income to pay for rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. Juliana will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more fabric, babies' wear and cosmetics to increase her sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Juliana plans to save towards a house she wants to put up for the child and herself.

loans.use: Juliana will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more fabric, babies' wear and cosmetics to increase the sale to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en: Leticia A. sells food supplies like rice, canned products, oil and spices at Coronation near Cape Coast. Leticia has received primary level education.  She is married and has 4 dependants. Her husband does printing works. Leticia has been selling food supplies since 1999. She is responsible for supporting her husband in paying rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to buy more food supplies to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards acquiring a piece of land for the building of the family house so that they can stop paying rent and also get a comfortable shelter for the family.

loans.use: Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to buy more food supplies to increase sale to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace K. is a single parent and has 4 dependants. She has received no formal education. Grace sells local dishes known as Banku and Kenkey and also fries fish at Coronation near Cape Coast, which she has done since 1987. Grace uses her income to pay for rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. Grace will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more corn to increase preparation and the sale of Banku and kenkey to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Grace plans to save towards acquiring a piece of land for the building of the family house so that they can stop paying rent and also get a comfortable shelter for the family.

loans.use: Grace will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more corn to increase preparation and the sale of Banku and kenkey to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Gertrude's Group

texts.en:
M. Getrude, a widow with 6 kids, runs a tailoring business. She has had a tailoring business for 20 years and specializes in traditional wear such as the one she has on. She says a big advantage of her business is she doesn't have to pay rent because she works out of her home. Apart from the tailoring business she is also a farmer. She grows vegetables and also has cows that give her milk for sale. 

She has benefitted from the loan because she has been able to construct commercial houses that provides rent income and help pay school fees. She believes her commercial houses will take care of her kids when she passes away.  

She is grateful to PEARL microfinance because without the loans she wouldn't have the capital to run her business, and through its profits, send her kids to school.

loans.use: Clothing materials for her tailoring business and complete the construction of her rental houses.

loans.name: Alimatu

texts.en: Alimatu Y. is married and has 2 children. She has received schooling through junior high. Alimatu sells cooked food at Cape Coast, which she has done since 2000. Her husband is a shoe dealer. Alimatu uses her income for supporting her husband in paying rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Alimatu will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more ingredients to increase the sale of the food she prepares to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Alimatu plans to save towards acquiring a piece of land for the building of the family house so that they can stop paying rent and also get a comfortable shelter for the family.

loans.use: Alimatu will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more ingredients to increase the sale of the food she prepares to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en: Linda Y. is a single parent and has 2 children. She has received no formal education. Linda sells clothing at Coronation near Cape Coast, which she has done since 2004. Linda uses her income to pay for rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. Linda will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more clothing to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Linda plans to save towards acquiring a piece of land for the building of the family house so that they can stop paying rent and also get a comfortable shelter for the family.

loans.use: Linda will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more clothing to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Norah's Group

texts.en: N. Norah, a widow and mother of 10 children, runs a retail shop business. She has been running this business for 10 years. She started the business with capital of her own. Soon after her husband passed away, she took loans to help fund the business. The key to her business success, she says, is a fridge that provides cold drinks and good customer service. Her business goal is to construct rental houses to provide additional income, one of which she has started already. The loans have enabled her to imrpove her well being and begin construction on her rental homes. This is her 24th loan.

loans.use: Restocking her business with cereals and cold drinks.

loans.name: Silvia

texts.en: Silvia A. sells cosmetics at Cape Coast. Silvia has received primary level education.  She is a single parent and has 2 children. Silvia has been selling cosmetics since 2007. She is responsible for paying rent, utility bills and other financial expenses . Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to buy more cosmetics to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards acquiring a piece of land for the building of the family house so that they can stop paying rent and also get a comfortable shelter for the family.

loans.use: Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to buy more cosmetics to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Zinaba

texts.en: Zinaba A. is a single parent and has 1 child. She has received schooling through junior high. Zinaba sells local dishes known as Kenkey and also fries fish at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast, which she has done since 1999. Zinaba uses her income to pay for rent, utility bills and other financial expenses . Zinaba will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more corn to increase the sales of kenkey to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Zinaba plans to save towards acquiring a piece of land for the building of the family house so that they can stop paying rent and also get a comfortable shelter for the family.

loans.use: Zinaba will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more corn to increase the sales of kenkey to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Edith's Group

texts.en:
N. Edith is the chairperson of the woman's group in Nakawuka. Edith has a stall at home where she sells firewood, cabbage, tomatoes etc. She has had the business for 9 years. Apart from the stall, she is a worker at a local shop, where she works from 8am to 1pm. By investing in her stall business she has been able to create profits that helps pay for her school feels, childrens' clothes, and their well-being. She says her business has been successful because of her friendly nature and work ethic. 

Edith is a widow with 8 children, out of which 2 are out of school. She has a dream of seeing all her kids go to school. (In the photo is Grace, the Coordinator)

loans.use: Vegetables to be sold at her home stall.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose N. is a single parent and has 7 dependants. She has received no formal education. Rose sells food supplies like tomatoes, maize, cassava and plantain at Coronation near Cape Coast, which she has done since 1977. Rose uses her income to pay for rent, utility bills and other financial expenses . Rose will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more food supplies to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Rose plans to save towards acquiring a piece of land for the building of the family house so that they can stop paying rent and also get a comfortable shelter for the family.

loans.use: Rose will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more food supplies to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en: Luisa A. sells groceries like biscuits, canned products and others at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast. Luisa has received senior high education. She is single and has no children. Luisa has been selling groceries since 2005. She is responsible for paying rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to buy more groceries to increase the sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards acquiring a piece of land for the building of the family house so that he can stop paying rent and also get a comfortable shelter for the family.

loans.use: Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to buy more groceries to increase the sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Annet's Group

texts.en: N. Annett, a married mother of 6 children, is the treasurer of the women's group of Kakawuka. She manages a poultry business as well as farming. Her farm consists of a banana plantation which she uses to make matoke, a local food staple, for sale and for consumption at home. She sometimes has difficulty managing her poultry business with high prices. She says being a friendly person has helped her to be successful in her business. She knows how to manage her finances because she is the treasurer of her lending group. She is grateful for the help of her husband who helps manage her loans. ( In the photo is Grace, the Coordinator)

loans.use: More chicks, chicken mash and labor on farm.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa A. is a hair dresser who owns a beauty salon at Abura. Theresa has received primary level education.  She is a single parent and has 5 dependants.  Theresa has been a hair dresser since about 2 years ago. She is responsible for paying rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. Her loan will be used to buy a variety of hair products to meet the demand of her costumers who come to the salon. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back for the expansion of  her trade .

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy a variety of hair products to meet the demand of her costumers who come to the salon.

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en: Salamatu G. is married and has 6 dependants. She has received schooling through senior high. Salamatu sells food supplies like cocoyam, eggs and plantain at Abura, which she has done since about 5 years ago. Salamatu uses her income to support her husband in paying rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Salamatu will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more food supplies to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Salamatu plans to reinvest back for the expansion of  her trade .

loans.use: Salamatu will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more food supplies to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Tahir

texts.en: Tahir M. sells food supplies like tomatoes, pepper and so on at Abura. Tahir has received no formal education.  She is married and has 2 children. Tahir has been selling food supplies since about 10 years ago. She is responsible for supporting her husband in paying rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to buy more food supplies to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back for the expansion of  her trade.

loans.use: Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to buy more food supplies to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Grecu's Group

texts.en:
Ostrovan R. is the leader of this group of people who want to all have their own business. R. before had borrowed a loan from MicroInvest and he repaid the money in full. This group is very united and all are very good friends between them. R. has shown MicroInvest the real correlatI. between these people. The main activity of this group is agriculture; all of them have a part of land near one another in their village, so the loan they borrowed is namely 4000 lei per each person of the group. With this money they want first of all to increase working capital and also to buy necessary seeds for vegetable growing. 

We want to thank Kiva lenders for helping this group of people.

loans.use: increase working capital

loans.name: Patience Efua

texts.en: Patience Efua M. is single and has no child. She has received schooling through senior high. Patience sells clothing and fabric; she is a seamstress who is specialized in sewing ladies wear at Ntabetil near Abura, which she has done since 2006. Patience uses her income to pay for housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family's financial needs. Patience will use the loan to purchase a variety of  fabrics and other sewing materials for her sewing work . With the new profits from her expanded business, Patience plans to reinvest back for the expansion of  her trade.

loans.use: Patience will use the loan to purchase a variety of  fabrics and other sewing materials for her sewing work .

loans.name: Kamu Kamu Group

texts.en: Helen A., a married mother of 3 children, is the treasurer of her loan group. She has belonged to the group for 8 years. She operates a bar, selling all kinds of drinks. She has been running  the bar for 12 years. She says the loans have been very helpful in uplifting her welfare and sending her children to school. Her children all attend university. She has no employees and runs the bar independently. Her goal for her business is simply for it to be able to fund her childrens' education. She believes her friendly nature attracts customers.

loans.use: Supplies for Bar/Restaurant

loans.name: Tukole Group

texts.en:
Jane B. is the chairperson of her borrower group. She is a tailor and poultry farmer. She has been in the tailoring business for 17 years, mainly dealing with school uniforms, traditional dresses and other casual wear. For 7 years she has been in the poultry business. The key to her business is customer loyalty. There are many other tailor shops but her customers choose to stick with her. 

Jane says the loans have been helping her so much to create more profits from her business, which she uses to pay school fees for her 5 children. Jane hopes to use the loans to expand her business while at the same time being able to cover her childrens' school fees. Jane's dream is to buy her own house to be able to retire to one day.

loans.use: supplies for tailor shop

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary Q. is married and has 2 children. She has received schooling through junior high. Mary sells used clothing at Abura, which she has done since about 5 years ago. Her husband is a carpenter. Mary uses her income to pay for housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family's financial needs. Mary will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of used clothing to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to reinvest back for the expansion of her trade.

loans.use: Mary will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of used clothing to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Evans

texts.en: Evans O. sells poultry fowls at Ntabetil near Abura. Evans has received junior high level education.  He is married and has 2 children. His wife is a trader. He buys the day-old chicks and rears them until they mature for consumption and then sells them. He has been doing this business for about 3 years now. He is responsible for paying rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. His loan will be used as additional capital to enable him to increase the sale of fowls to meet the increase in demand by his costumers. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to reinvest back for the expansion of his trade.

loans.use: His loan will be used as additional capital to enable him to increase the sale of fowls to meet the increase in demand by his costumers.

loans.name: Bakuddeube Group

texts.en: Hanifa Kimela, a widow with 4 children, has been a tailor for about 7 years. She has belonged to her lending group for 1 and a half years. She works mainly on uniforms and traditional dresses. She attracts customers through her wide selection of materials. She also has a land that she is trying to develop into a farm to bring additional income. Her future goal is to construct a house in town.

loans.use: expanding tailor shop

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice O. is a single parent and has 2 children. She has received schooling through senior high. Beatrice sells food supplies at Abura, which she has doing for about 10 years. Beatrice uses her income to pay for housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family’s financial needs. Beatrice will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more food supplies to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Beatrice plans to reinvest back for the expansion of her trade.

loans.use: Beatrice will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more food supplies to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en: Cynthia K. is married and has 2 children. She has received schooling through senior high. Cynthia sells eggs at Pedu near Abura, and has done so for about 12 years now. Her husband is in the telecommunications business. Cynthia uses her income to pay for housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family’s financial needs. Cynthia will use the loan  as additional capital to enable her to buy more eggs to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Cynthia plans to reinvest back for the expansion of her trade.

loans.use: Cynthia will use the loan  as additional capital to enable her to buy more eggs to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria H.  is 56 years old and she lives in Cahul district, Vadul lu Isac village. In order to survive she needs to sell goods at the wholesale market in the district. Her husband does not work now because he is very ill but he tries to help Maria when he can, namely to plough the land and also to care for their 3 children. Maria’s family is having a hard time just surviving, but now Maria decided to take out a loan from MicroInvest to increase her sales; hopefully it will be easier for her family in future.

We want to thank Kiva lenders for their help and of course for their desire to help people like Maria.

loans.use: increase working capital

loans.name: Víctor Albino

texts.es:
El señor Víctor Albino I. padre de familia, tiene 2 hijos los cuales actual mente están estudiando y quiere lo mejor para ellos.
Don Víctor Albino esta pagando lo que es el puro terreno y con mucho esfuerzo y ahorros empezó a construir al grado de terminar su vivienda pero nada más le está haciendo falta los acabados del exterior e interior  para tenerla terminada y darle a su familia un patrimonio segura.
texts.en:
Victor Albino I. is the father of a family, and has two children who are actually studying and he wants the best for them. Victor Albino is paying what is actually just land, and with much strength and savings he started to build the degree to finish his home but he is no longer doing it because he lacks the exterior and interior items to have it finished and give his family a secure home.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Exterior and interior finishings

loans.name: Porfirio

texts.es:
El señor Porfirio M. tiene ya más de 2 años dedicándose a su negocio de venta de abarrotes, este es el ingreso de su familia.
    Al negocio les esta haciendo más variedad de mercancía como es venta de verduras, lácteos, papelería y uniformes escolares. Pero en esté momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para invertir en el negocio y está solicitando un préstamo para poder llevar a cabo está inversión. Planea pagar el crédito con los ingresos que genera el negocio ya que es la única tienda de la colonia y tiene muy buenas ventas.
texts.en:
Mr Porfirio M. has been selling groceries for more than 2 years. This is the family's income. His business needs a bigger variety of goods such as vegetables, milk, stationery and school uniforms. But at this moment, he doesn't have the necessary money to invest in the business, therefore he is requesting a loan to be able to do it. He plans to repay the loan with the income generated from the sales since his grocery shop is the only one in the neighborhood and he has very good sales.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise for his business

loans.name: Flor De Canela Group

texts.es:
La asociación Flor de Canela esta formada por 15 mujeres ansiosas de mejorar en sus pequeños negocios, se reúnen cada dos semanas, en el centro focal Villa Adela ubicado en la avenida Bolivia de la ciudad de El Alto. Diversas son las actividades de este grupo, algunas realizan tejidos artesanales; otras confeccionan y arreglan prendas de vestir, también se dedican a la elaboración y venta de alimentos, Lucrecia por ejemplo elabora embutidos de carne de vaca y cerdo.
Todas ellas afirman que necesitan de créditos para  ampliar sus negocios, con la seguridad de obtener mayores ventas y de este modo obtener mejores  ingresos para sus familias.
texts.en:
The “Flor de Canela” association is comprised of 15 women eager to improve their small businesses. They meet every two weeks in the center of Villa Adela, located on Bolivia Avenue in the city of El Alto. The group’s activities are diverse, some making handcrafted knits, others make clothing and also dedicate themselves to preparing and selling food. Lucrecia, for example, makes beef and pork sausages. They all affirm that they need the loans to expand their enterprises, with the assurance of making more sales and therefore earning a better income for their families.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: They need the loan to expand their businesses.

loans.name: Rafael

texts.es:
El señor Rafael T. H. es Casado, en su casa vive el su esposa y un nieto el cual están a cargo. La hija del señor falleció de un derrame cerebral por lo que el niño quedo huérfano, Eduardo su nieto  de 13 años el acaba de entrar al primer año de secundaria y el señor Rafael se preocupa mucho por el bienestar de su familia por eso poco a poco le ha ido  haciendo mejoras a su casa, la planta baja ya esta terminada solo le falta la parte alta y nos solicita un préstamo para iniciar su proyecto.
El es chofer de una empresa de la ciudad y su esposa ser dedica al hogar al cuidado de su nieto.
texts.en:
Rafael T. H. is married and lives with his wife and a grandson for whom they care. Rafael’s daughter died from a brain hemorrhage, which left the grandson an orphan. Eduardo, his grandson, is just 13 years old and starting in his first year of secondary school. Rafael worries a great deal about the well-being of his family which is the reason why, little by little, he has undertaken making improvements to his house. The lower level is now completed, leaving only the top floor to finish and he requests a loan from us to start on this project. He is a driver at one of the city’s enterprises, and his wife takes care of the home and their grandson.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay for construction materials and labor.

loans.name: Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.es:
A la cabeza de Olga L. trece mujeres trabajan junto a Pro-Mujer hace seis años aproximadamente, se reúnen quincenalmente, en el centro focal de  Villa Exaltación, donde realizan sus actividades de manera responsable. Existen diversos negocios dentro la asociación, algunas  son costureras, otras se dedican al tejido y venta de chompas, también elaboran ladrillos para luego venderlos a pedido.
La asociación Nueva Esperanza” necesita ampliar sus ventas por lo que necesitan comprar materia prima, tienen la certeza que generaran mayores ingresos, únicamente con el fin de mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Together with Olga L., thirteen women have been working with Pro-Mujer for approximately six years. They meet every two weeks, in the center of Villa Exaltación, where they carry out their activities in a responsible manner. A diversity of businesses exist within the group, some are seamstresses, other dedicate themselves to knitting and selling sweaters, and they also make bricks to later sell on order. The association “Nueva Esperanza” (“New Hope”) needs to grow its sales so they can buy raw materials. They are certain of their ability to generate added income, with the final aim of improving their standards of living.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase raw materials.

loans.name: Leonor

texts.es: Leonor A. vive en Zacatecoluca departamento de la Paz, Leonor  vive con su esposo y con sus hijos aun menores de edad. Leonor se dedica a la venta de mariscos diariamente viaja hasta el muelle a comprar lo que venderá en el día, luego se va al mercado central de Zacatecoluca y de manera ambulante se pasea por todo el mercado gritando sus precios y ofreciendo su venta de pescado y camarones. Leonor solicita un crédito para poder comprar mariscos.
texts.en:
Leonor A. lives in the Zacatecoluca departament of La Paz, along with her husband and young children. Leonor dedicates herself to the sale of seafood, and travels to the docks on a daily basis to buy what she will be selling during the day. Later, she goes to the market in Zacatecoluca and travels throughout it on foot yelling out her prices and offering her fish and shrimp for sale. Leonor requests a loan to be able to purchase seafood.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase seafood.

loans.name: Leonardo

texts.es: Leonardo M. vive en Cantón Tierra Colorada, en el departamento de la paz junto a su esposa e hijos. Leonardo es un hombre trabajador que ha logrado montar su propio negocio, viendo las necesidades en los habitantes del cantón, Leonardo se anima a poner un molino en su casa luego de mucho esfuerzo y con una entusiasmo de superación expande su negocio montando otro molino pero en el centro de su pueblo, ahora Leonardo solicita un crédito para poder comprar un motor eléctrico para que su molino sea más eficiente y así poder atender una mayor cantidad de clientes.
texts.en:
Leonardo M. lives in Tierra Colorada, in the department of La Paz with his wife and children. Leonardo is a hard-working man who has managed to open his own business, selling staple goods to the inhabitants of the district. Leonardo decided to open a mill in his home. After a great deal of effort and with enthusiasm to overcome all obstacles, he expanded his business and opened another mill. This second mill is located in the centre of his village. Now, Leonardo is asking for a loan to buy an electric motor so that his mill can work more efficiently so that he can serve a greater number of customers.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy an electric motor for his mill

loans.name: Josefa

texts.es: Josefa Z. vive en Zacatecoluca departamento  La Paz, Josefa vive con sus dos hijas que son madres solteras y sus nietos, Josefa se dedica a la venta de mariscos, todos los días sale desde muy temprano de su casa al muelle El Malecón, para comprar de las pesca más fresca luego se desplaza para vender sus maricos  en el  mercado del pueblo donde ella reside. Ahora Josefa solicita un crédito para poder adquirir mayor cantidad de mariscos y así obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Josefa Z. lives in Zacatecoluca, in the department of La Paz. Josefa lives with her two daughter, who are single mothers, and her grandchildren. Josefa sells seafood: every day she leaves home very early for the El Malecón pier in order to buy the freshest fish. She walks throughout the village market of her village to sell her seafood. Now, Josefa is asking for a loan to buy fish in larger quantities and therefore make more profit.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seafood for retail

loans.name: Jazmín Lisseth

texts.es: Jazmín Lisseth D. L. tiene 30 años D. edad, vive con su esposo en Atiquizaya  departamento D. Ahuachapán,  Jazmín y su esposo se dedican a su negocio que es un comedor,  idea que nace tras muchos intentos D. ambos buscando empleos , pero tras no encontrar un salario que les ayudara a subsistir, Jazmín tuvo la idea que con sus conocimientos en cocina y la ayuda D. su esposo en atender a los clientes podrían llevar a cabo montar un comedor;  y así es como lo hacen,  con muchos sacrificios esta pareja ha logrado alquilar un pequeño local donD. se han instalado con un pequeño comedor que le llamaron “El Portal del tío Memo” donD. ambos se reparten labores y logran atender con satisfacción a sus clientes, Jazmín solicita un crédito para compra D. provisiones  alimenticias para su comedor.
texts.en:
Jazmín Lisseth D. L. is 30 years old. She lives with her husband in Atiquizaya in the department of Ahuachapán. Jazmín and her husband run a diner, which began as an idea when both were looking for work but were unabled to find jobs which paid enough to survive on. Jazmín had the idea that with her knowledge of cooking and her husband's help in caring for customers they would be able to run a successful diner. And so they have, with much sacrifice this couple have managed to rend a small locale where they opened a little diner which they called "El Portal del tío Memo” where they each have their tasks and manage to care for their customers. Jazmín is asking for a loan to buy foodstuffs for her diner.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs for her diner

loans.name: Juana Elsy

texts.es: Juana Elsy M. D. L., vive en Zacatecoluca departamento La Paz, junto a su esposo y dos hijos menores D. edad. Si bien el esposo D. Elsy es hombre responsable con la familia no es suficiente para los gastos a la que la familia se enfrenta mes a mes, ya que sus hijos estudian la secundaria; lo cual implica esfuerzos económicos para estos padres, es por ello que Elsy  se decidió en  buscar una fuente D. ingreso , pero lastimosamente Elsy solo ha cursado su nivel educativo básico razón por la cual no pueD. competir con muchas personas calificadas que buscan  un empleo, es por ello que Elsy se decidió con el apoyo D. su esposo a alquilar un espacio en el mercado municipal del pueblo donD. vive,  para poner una  venta D. ropa . Ahora Elsy solicita un crédito para comprar mercadería y D. esta manera emplearía el margen D. sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Juana Elsy M. D. L. lives in Zacatecoluca in the department of La Paz with her husband and two minor children. Even though Elsy's husband is a responsible man, his income is not enough to pay the family's expenses month after month. Because their children are in high school, Elsy and her husband are faced with financial difficulties. For this reason Elsy decided to find another source of income. Unfortunately, Elsy has only an elementary education and so is not in a position to compete for jobs with people with better qualifications. With her husband support, Elsy decided to rent a locale in the municipal market of the town they live in, in order to sell clothing. Now, Elsy is asking for a loan to buy merchandise and in this way she will increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing for retail

loans.name: Alice's Group

texts.en:
Alice N. is the chairperson of Kayunga Basooka Kwavula lending group. Her business is poultry and she has 300 chickens in total. She has had the business for 4 years.

Alice is married with 7 children, and cares for 3 orphans. She has a plan of developing her business by selling chicken eggs. Alice has a dream of building a bigger house and a bigger farm for her chickens. She uses her loans to pay for chicken fees and the costs of transporting the chickens, and to expand her chicken farm.

loans.use: Chicken fees, feed and expansion with more buildings.

loans.name: Farida's Group

texts.en:
Farida N. is a devoted and hardworking lady with a business selling old clothes to customers in the various market areas. She has been in the business for over 10 years now, which has won her many customers. The only challenge she has now is over moving to various destinations on a truck which is a bit risky for one’s life but apart from that, she loves what she does.

She wakes up early in the morning and attends to her farm as well as arranging her home and after that she sets out to go and sell clothes. She has been able to buy a plot of land, build a house and buy many household items, making her standard of living better. Farida needs a new loan to help with stocking her business with a new bale of clothes from Kampala that will fetch more money.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes in a bale for sale.

loans.name: Alice's Group

texts.en:
Alice N. is the leader of her lgroup. She is a married lady with a poultry business where she keeps both layers and broiler chickens (over 300 in total), as well as having a retail shop that contributes highly to her weekly income of 50,000 Ushs. As a result, Alice has been able to pay school fees for her children as well as to buy more household items like a sofa set and a sewing machine, which she uses to mend people’s clothes. She has a hope of developing her sewing business so as to have more avenues of money-making.

Alice needs a loan to help with buying chicken feed and stocking her shop.

loans.use: To buy more chicken feed and restock her shop.

loans.name: Harriet's Group

texts.en: Harriet K. is the leader of her group in Jinja. She is a devoted married lady working closely with her husband in their family wholesale shop. They have had the shop for 11 years. Harriet has so far taken 16 loans from her group, each payable in four months. She is so grateful that using the loans has helped her so much in stocking their shop with the desired products in large quantities. They get their products from Kenya, Kampala and some of them in Jinja where prices are low and this has helped to fetch them profits. Recently they were able to transform to selling to some retailers and so far they have not regretted their move. Harriet needs a loan to be able to buy more stock like sugar, soap, cooking oil and Vaseline for her shop.

loans.use: Restocking her family wholesale shop.

loans.name: Ahamada's Group

texts.en: Ahamada H. is a member of Akuwa Ekibono group in Jinja. He is a married man with 6 children and he cares for 4 other relatives. Ahamada has been managing his retail shop for 9 years, a shop he created from the profits got from his farming business, and this is now mainly managed by his wife. Apart from building a house for his family, he has also bought another plot of land with the hope of constructing residential houses that will cater for his children’s school fees up to University level. He needs a loan to help with employing labor on his farm to supplement the force employed by his wife, and to buy seedlings. The balance will help to restock his retail shop with more products.

loans.use: Restock his shop, buy seedlings and hire labor for his farm.

loans.name: Samuel's Group

texts.en: M. Samuel is a member of his lending group in Jinja. He is a married man with six children, all still in school as he also cares for the three orphans of his late brothers. He has a retail shop in the Ivunamba trading centre and he is grateful that all the loans he has been taking have been helpful in his business and with his family at large since by stocking his shop, he has been able to make profits, hence being able to pay school fees for his children and attending to their healthcare. Samuel is also a farmer and from this, he is able to save money to buy food as well as being able to sell the excess. He now needs another loan to be able to buy more stock for his shop like sugar, books, beans, maize seeds, and other things.

loans.use: Restocking his retail shop

loans.name: Annet's Group

texts.en: Annet N. is a hard-working single mother of four children, all of whom are in school. She has a business of managing her retail shop that she has owned for six years so far. As a result, she has been able to buy a plot of land for her children, attend to their medical bills, clothe them, as well as feed them single-handedly. Annet is not certain whether she would have managed without the help of loans and has no hope of giving up on borrowing. She now needs another loan to help with restocking her shop with more products for making more profits.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop

loans.name: Jessica's Group

texts.en: Jessica M. is the chairperson of the Waina Group in Jinja. She is married with eight children, three of whom are still in school. Jessica has a tailoring business where she makes and mends clothes especially for women and children, not men. The reason for this is that men never believe that a woman can ever make their clothes right. She has been in the business for over ten years and had never received a loan elsewhere until two years ago when she joined Pearl Microfinance. Jessica is grateful that in such a short time, she has been able to buy another sewing machine, making it three, with one used for training young girls how to sew, one for her business, and another which she uses at home. Jessica needs a loan to buy clothing materials and other accessories like threads and needles for her business.

loans.use: To purchase clothing materials and other accessories for her business

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica A. is a single parent and has two children. She has completed schooling through the junior high level. Veronica sells fabric at Kakumdo near Abura, something she has done for about three years now. Veronica uses her income to pay for rent, utility bills, and other financial expenses. Veronica will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to buy more fabric to increase sales to meet the increase in demand from her costumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Veronica plans to reinvest in the expansion of her trade.

loans.use: To buy more fabric to resell

loans.name: Masitula's Group

texts.en: Masitula N. is one of the executive members of the Lugolole Group in Jinja. She is a married woman and has a business of selling bananas (matooke). She has been in this business all her life and hence has the experience of ensuring that she has high yields since most of the matooke she sells come from her garden. She will only go to her fellow matooke growers if she does not have enough to sell to her customers. Apart from the matooke, Masitula also has other sweet potato plantations, cassava, and groundnuts that help to boost her income. She also keeps animals like cows and goats at home and has bicycles that help to transport her produce to the desired market areas. Masitula needs a loan to help buy fertilizers for her farm and to employ manpower on those farms.

loans.use: To pay for more fertilizers and labor on her farm plantations

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam D. is married and has one child. She has received schooling through junior high level. Mariam is a hairdresser who owns a beauty salon at Abura, which she has done for about 5 years. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Mariam uses her income to help her husband pay rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Mariam will use the loan to purchase different varieties of hair products to meet the demand of her customers who come to the salon. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mariam plans to reinvest for the expansion of her little salon.

loans.use: purchase different varieties of hair products

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort N. sells used clothing at Abura. Comfort has received junior high school education. She is married and has 5 children. Her husband is a building painter.

Comfort has been selling used clothing for about 2 years. She is responsible for paying housekeeping expenses. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of used clothing to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits to reinvest for the expansion of her little business.

loans.use: additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of used clothing

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther M. sells used clothing and food supplies at Abura. Esther has received senior high school education. She is married and has 5 dependents. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Esther has been selling used clothing and food supplies for about 5 years now. She is responsible for paying housekeeping expenses and other family expenses. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of used clothing and food supplies to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits to reinvest for the expansion of her businesses.

loans.use: additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of used clothing and food supplies

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba A. sells palm oil and also deals in "gari" which is made out of cassava. Gari is eaten widely by most people in the country. Her business is located at Kakumdo near Abura. Aba has received primary school level of education. She is married and has 6 dependents. Her husband is a fisherman.

Aba has been selling palm oil and other food supplies for about 5 years now. She is responsible for paying housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family’s other financial needs. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to buy more cassava to increase her sales of gari and palm oil as well to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits to reinvest for the expansion of her business.

loans.use: additional capital to enable her to buy more cassava and palm oil

loans.name: Dan Bright

texts.en: Dan Bright N. has a book shop and he is involved in petty trading at Kakumdo near Abura. He also manufactures soap for sale. Dan Bright has received tertiary level education.  He is married and has 6 dependants. His wife is a trader. Dan Bright has a book shop and has also been doing petty trading about 5 years ago. He started his soap manufacturing business not to long ago. He is responsible for paying rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. His loan will be used to as additional capital to enable him to buy more raw materials to increase the production and sale of the soap he makes as well as investing in his other business to meet the increase in demand by his costumers. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to reinvest back for the expansion of his trade.

loans.use: His loan will be used to as additional capital to enable him to buy more raw materials to increase the production and sale of the soap he makes as well as investing in his other business to meet the increase in demand by his costumers.

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en: Sabina S. is married and has 3 children. She has received schooling through primary level. Sabina sells soaps at Abura, which she has done for about 3 years ago. Her husband is a mason. Sabina uses her income to pay for housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family’s financial needs. Sabina will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of soaps to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Sabina plans to reinvest back for the expansion of her trade.

loans.use: Sabina will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of soaps to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes M. sells food supplies at Kakumdo near Abura. Agnes has received no formal education.  She is a single parent and has 4 dependants. Agnes has been selling food supplies for about 6 years now. She is responsible for paying rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. Her loan will be used as capital to enable her to buy more food supplies to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back for the expansion of her trade.

loans.use: Her loan will be used as capital to enable her to buy more food supplies to increase sales to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Prince

texts.en: Prince O. is single and has no children. He has received schooling through junior high. Prince sells LP Gas cylinders and stoves at Kotokraba which is the heart of Cape Coast, which he has done since 2005.  Prince uses his income to pay for rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. Prince will use the loan as additional capital to enable him to increase the sale of LP Gas cylinders to meet the increase in demand by him costumers. With the new profits from his expanded business, Prince plans to put up a building for  himself and for the future family he will be having.

loans.use: Prince will use the loan as additional capital to enable him to increase the sale of LP Gas cylinders to meet the increase in demand by him costumers.

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity A. sells phones and accessories at Kotokraba which is the heart of Cape Coast. Charity has received junior high education.  She is married and has no children. Her husband is a trader. Charity has been selling phones and accessories since 2000. She is responsible for supporting her husband in paying rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of phones and accessories to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards acquiring a piece of land for the building of the family house so that they can stop paying rent and also get a comfortable shelter for the family.

loans.use: Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of phones and accessories to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: David A.

texts.en: David A. B. is married and has 4 dependents. He has received schooling through junior high. David A. sells phone spare parts at Kotokraba, the heart of Cape Coast, which he has done since 2002. His wife is a trader. David A. uses his income to pay for the children's school fees and provide food, clothing and other basic needs of the family. David A. will use the loan as additional capital to enable him increase the sale of phone spare parts to meet the increase in demand by his customers. With the new profits from his expanded business, David A. plans to invest in the children's education.

loans.use: Buy phone spare parts

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama A. is widow and has 3 children. She has received schooling through junior high. She sells groceries like biscuits, canned products and other food supplies at Tatermu near Elmina, which she has done since not too long ago. Ama uses her income to pay for the children's school fees, rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. Ama will use the loan as additional capital to enable her increase the sale of groceries to meet the increase in demand by her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama plans to reinvest for the expansion of her trade.

loans.use: Buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: James

texts.en: James A. sells phones and accessories at Kotokraba, which is the heart of Cape Coast. James has received a junior high education.  He is married and has no children. His wife is a trader. James has been selling phones and accessories since 2000. He is responsible for providing food, clothing and other basic needs of the family. His loan will be used as additional capital to enable him increase the sale of phones and accessories to meet the increase in demand by his customers. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to put up a building for the family.

loans.use: Purchsase more inventory

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en: Thomas A. sells electrical appliances at Tatermu near Elmina. Thomas has received no formal education.  He is single and has no children.Thomas has been selling electrical appliances since 2002. He is responsible for paying the fees for his siblings in school. His loan will be used as additional capital to enable him to increase the sale of electrical appliances to meet the increase in demand by his customers. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to reinvest for the expansion of his trade.

loans.use: Buy more electrical appliances

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi E. sells underwear and clothing at Akotobinsin near Elmina. Naomi has received a commercial education. She is married and has 1 child. Her husband is an auto electrician. Naomi has been selling underwear and clothing for a short time. She is responsible for assisting her husband with the housekeeping expenses. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her increase the sale of underwear and clothing to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back for the expansion of her trade.

In the basket beside her are some fabric samples of what she sells.

loans.use: Purchase more inventory

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena B. sells local dishes known as Obrayo and also fries fish for sale at Tatermu near Elmina. Abena has received a primary level education.  She is married and has 2 children. Her husband is a minister. Abena has been selling local dishes since 1997. She is responsible for assisting her husband with the housekeeping expenses. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her buy more corn. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest for the expansion of her trade.

loans.use: Buy more corn

loans.name: Kate

texts.en: Kate A. is married and has 6 dependents. She has received schooling through primary level. Kate sells cooked food at Tatermu near Elmina, which she started not too long ago. Her husband is a commercial driver. Kate uses her income to assist her husband with the housekeeping expenses. Kate will use the loan to enable her buy more ingredients to increase the sale of the food she prepares. With the new profits from her expanded business, Kate plans to invest in the children's education.

loans.use: Buy more ingredients

loans.name: Fustina

texts.en: Fustina E. sells groceries like biscuits, canned products and other items at Bronibima near Elmina. Fustina has received a junior high education.  She is married and has 4 dependents. Her husband is a construction worker. Fustina started selling groceries not too long ago. She is responsible for assisting her husband with the housekeeping expenses. Her loan will be used to buy groceries to meet the demand from her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest for the expansion of her trade.

loans.use: Buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Both

texts.en: S. is 41 years old and a resident of the Kompong Tom Province. She is a mother of two children; the first one works as a laborer in the private sector, and the other is a student. S. is married to Khy, 20, who works in housing as a wood provider. S. has been earning her living by raising pigs in the stall behind her house since 2002. She sells them for slaughter in four months time after raising. She gets up every morning to buy the pigs' food and sometimes she buys their food from the market. S. is now looking for a loan to buy a buffalo for her husband's business in transferring the housing wood. She dreams of having a good living, a good house, and a degree for her child.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo for her husband's business in lumber transferring

loans.name: Chheng

texts.en:
Mrs. M., 44, has been running a medium-sized store out of her home for a long time, selling different kinds of groceries such as cooked ingredients and canned food. She normally sells her items to villagers, and is currently earning approximately US$ 3 per day. She is married to Mr. Chem, 35, who is a domestic building worker, and who also helps her in selling groceries.

M. is a mother who has three children; two of them are married and the other one is single and attends school. M. has applied for a US$ 1000 loan to purchase more grocery inventory for sale. The family lives in Battambang Province, Cambodia.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery inventory for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding to earn more income.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to  buy more traditional medicines for her husband's practice

loans.name: Sin

texts.en: R. is 35 years old and a resident of the Kompong Tom Province in Cambodia. He has two children, both of whom are single and students. R. is married to Sina who sells sweets in the market. He earns his living by burning wood into charcoal and selling them to the markets. R. gets up every morning to go to his field and comes back home in the late afternoon in his bare feet. He pulls with his strong body, a cart between his field and home, and then to the market. Recently, R. requested a loan to buy a pair of buffaloes to pull his cart. He dreams of having a good living, a good house, and degrees for his children. R. was not available during the photograph, so his wife is shown instead.

loans.use: To buy a pair of buffaloes to pull his cart

loans.name: Phum's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of three people. Its leader, Mrs. S., age 35, is a domestic rice trader. She usually collects rice from rice farmers in the village to stock and later on resell to gain income. She only makes a daily income of around $5 each day to help meet the family's expenses. She is married with three children; all three of whom are teenagers and under her care, whilst her husband, Sean, 54, works as a staff member for a ministry of telecommunication. S.'s investment is going well because it is a profitable investment for the family. To enlarge the business, she is asking for a loan to buy additional rice stocks to sell. 
The other two borrowers are:
S., 26, who sells groceries. She is requesting a loan to buy grocery inventory to sell.
S. M., age 46, is a widow. She currently sells soybean juice, and she needs a loan to expand her business. 
The borrowers all live in the Battambang Province of Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy additional rice stocks to sell

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en: Mr. Vorn T. is a villager in Ba Khung Khang Koeut village in Takeo province. He and his wife, Mrs. Nou Uok, are farmers who own a plot of land used to cultivate rice. On this plantation, they do not earn enough income to support their family. In order to improve their life, Mr. Vorn T. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike to start a motor taxi business. He is 60 years old, the father of three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory and the third attends the local school. His wife is presented on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to start a motor taxi business.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a 58-year-old woman and happily married to Mr. Apolinario M., a farmer, carpenter, and loving husband.  They were blessed with six children, three girls and three boys. Esther is already on her sixth cycle of her loan availment. Her business is named “M. Store,” one that retails food and household items. Her usual customers are students, municipal employees, and also the folks of the neighboring barangays. Her business is growing and customers are increasing.  

She has requested a loan amounting to PHP 26,000, hoping that this will help her in purchasing additional grocery items and the existing needs of her present customers.

Esther believes that the business could grow larger and more stable in the future if it will be managed correctly.  She’s so thankful for Paglaum’s existence in the community and its program components that helped them realize the significance of patience and hardwork.

loans.use: To buy more food and household items to sell in her store

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Mrs. B. became a Paglaum Member on May 05, 2008. She is 49 years old, and lives in West Poblacion, Rizal, Zambo, Norte. She is a widow, and has four children: one is in college and the other three are in high school. 

Being a single parent of four children, she must always work hard for a living. She has faced many obstacles and challenges along their way. Her husband died young due to severe sickness.

Before she became a member of PDP-LP she already had a small business. She is now requesting her second loan, a loan of PHP 5,000.00 to buy assorted grocery items such as vegetables and spices. She also sells banana cues (bananas dipped in brown sugar and deep fried). Her usual customers are students, strangers passing by, teachers, municipal employees, and many others because her business is located along the National Highway near a school. Her business is growing and the number of customers is increasing.

She hopes that the business will grow bigger and more stable in the future, so that she can sustain their living. Like other parents, she is working hard for her children. She dreams that all of them can complete college and be able to support themselves. She is grateful for Paglaum’s presence in her community, for its programs and its services that help people realize the importance of savings, insurance, and social responsibility.

loans.use: Purchase grocery items

loans.name: Koem Sieng

texts.en: Mrs. Koem Sieng C. lives in Boeung village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land used to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Dorn Sina, is a popular musician who is hired to perform at wedding ceremonies, parties, and so on. They do not earn enough money to build a kitchen. Therefore, Mrs. Koem Sieng C. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings in order to build the kitchen for her family. She is 45 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory and the others are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is shown on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To add to her savings to build a kitchen for her family.

loans.name: Samai

texts.en: Mrs. Samai Y. is a villager in Doem Roes village in Kandal province. She is a housewife. Her husband, Mr. Chhorn Sokchea, is a hard working construction worker. He has a problem because he does not have enough construction supplies to support his work. Mrs. Samai Y. decided to request a loan to buy construction supplies for her husband’s work. She is 51 years old and a mother of four children; two of her children are employed in a garment factory and two attend the local school. Her husband is shown on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies for her husband’s work.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Roderick

texts.en:
PMPC was created to give programs and services to those who are in need of financial assistance and to provide training with regards to business. 

Mr. Roderick I. became a member of Paglaum on January 23, 2009. Roderick lacked financial capital for his sari-sari store. (The word sari-sari is Tagalog for "various kinds." Most sari-sari stores are privately owned shops that are operated inside the shopkeeper's home.) Roderick only had  enough money to build the sari-sari. His mother encouraged him to become a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Coop so he could borrow the money to buy assorted grocery items such as canned goods, noodles, assorted snacks, oils, spices, and many other items. He is requesting PHP 5,000.00 as start-up capital for his business. His wife will manage the store. 

Roderick has a job at the Municipal Nursery.  He is thankful that he has additional income for his family and that his wife will be having fun managing their business. In the future, Roderick hopes to expand his sari-sari to a mini grocery store and to have a house of their own for his family.

loans.use: Purchase supplies for his store

loans.name: Yon

texts.en: Mrs. S., 29, has owned a plot of farmland since 1999. She grows different kinds of vegetables, such as cabbage and morning glories. She is married to Chon, 35, who helps her grow vegetables. The couple has two teenage children, who are in school. The family lives in Kompong Cham Province. Mrs. S. is applying for a $900 loan to buy fertilizer, insecticide, a pump, gasoline, and a cow. (Mrs. S.'s husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, insecticides, a pump, gasoline, and a cow

loans.name: Anafe

texts.en:
Anafe R., 30, and her husband Mr. Felecito R., who is a fisherman, are blessed with three children. They live in Pta. Miray, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. Anafe became a member of PDP-LP (the Micro- finance program of Paglaum MPC) on August 27, 2004. She is a very hardworking person who started her own small business to generate additional income for her family. She says "if we only depend on the income of my husband from fishing, it is not enough to support our daily needs.”  She bakes "pan Bisaya," a native bread that is cooked in a Hornohan (a clay oven that uses firewood for cooking). 

Anafe has taken out loans to purchase ingredients for her bread-making business. With her profits, she purchased an unfinished fishing boat. Now Anafe is requesting her eighth loan. She is requesting PHP 5,000.00 to purchase materials and paints to finish her fishing boat.

Anafe is grateful that she became a member of Paglaum because Paglaum's  financial services and low interest rates have helped her a lot. Her future plan is to acquire a motor for her fishing boat to help increase their income. Her ambitions in life are to have a decent home for her family and to see her three children graduate from college.

loans.use: To finish her boat

loans.name: San's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of three women who live in Battambang Province. The leader is K., 28, who has two very young children.
